title: Inverted Yield Curve
text:
Actually, yield-curve inversion means that short-term rates may fall. Normally, that also means that long-term rates would fall too. The issue is how far 30-yr can fall from 2% now? Is the US heading to negative yield [YTM] for 30-yr?

Conventional wisdom is that when yield-curve inverts, it is bullish for bonds and one goes long. Is it different this time?

IMO, it is good to pocket good yield short-term [T-Bills, m-mkt funds] as well have some exposure to general/intermediate term bond funds and multisector bond funds. Let the big boys play with 30-yr and zeros.

YBB
description: What to expect with an inverted yield curve? Will monthly dividends drop by a lot in funds like VG Total Bond Market? I won't actually make a move with - 19092
